title: The Untold Story of Discord: "Pivots and F*ck Ups..."

rawLines.text: I think half of that group of 18 people
thought that Discord was a [ __ ]
horrible idea. One of the employees quit
through Post-it note. When I started it,
I was like, if we get the whole market,
we'll have 100 million monthly
activives. That would be like complete
slam dunk. Game over. We win. Jason
Citron is the co-founder of Discord. In
this speedrun session, Jason walks
through the tough pivot from making
games to making a communication
platform, the early days of building
Discord, and what it really takes to
lead through times of uncertainty.
Jason's worked on multiple companies,
but but one of the most interesting
aspects of uh Discord is that famously
this company actually started out as um
Hammer and Chisel, which was building a
game called Fates Forever and then
pivoted, you know, later. So, we want to
kind of go back in the time machine and
actually just zoom in on that that exact
like decision to pivot. What did you
see? How did you, you know, decide? And
so, yeah. Tell tell us about kind of the
earliest days. Yeah. So, fuckups, huh?
Um,
well, no, no, you're you're doing
pivoting. I was doing I was Oh, you were
doing the [ __ ] up. Exactly. It's Well,
see, the thing about pivots is they feel
like fuckups actually. Like people talk
about pivoting like, "Oh, you know,
yeah, maybe you'll pivot." It's not fun
at all to go through that to go through
those kind of experiences because the
the lived reality of going through a
pivot is that you've just spent some
amount of time pouring your heart into
building some product and it's not
working and coming to the realization of
that and then thinking about like now
what it it's it actually emotionally was
like was very hard. If you know if you
have clear eyes and you see what's

about how do you know uh what what do
you do from there? So while we built
this game and launched it in 2014 called
Fates Forever, it was kind of like a
competitive multiplayer game on iPad
three versus three team based game for a
variety of reasons it didn't work and
but the plan for the company from from
the original sort of founding when I
started it was to actually build a chat
app for gaming and the thought was that
we would bootstrap the social network
through a communic through through a
game and not actually go to market
directly with the chat app. So, we built
the game and we had voice voice and text
chat built into it, team play. We
actually built a forum, custom forum
that was integrated with the game that
had a lot of community activity. And
when the game didn't work, what we
realized was kind of a couple things.
One is that we noticed some some things
about how people were organizing around
our game and what apps they were using
and how they were cobbling together mass
market communication apps to talk with
their friends and maintain their sort of
guilds across game sessions. And then
that made us notice our own behavior
using things like Skype and TeamSpeak at
the time and how we played games
ourselves. We're thinking about like
okay what do we do do next? Do we try to
make a game again or do we you know
should we is there a path to go directly
to market with a communications app and
ultimately you know we saw a path to
just launch a chat app directly that we
didn't have to bootstrap it with a game

umbrella of of of our search space. Was
it was it obvious that you had to work
on something else or was it you know
like why not actually just continue to
